<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 114, 606, 139]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 161, 185, 192]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 210, 163, 240]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 203, 395, 247]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[591, 210, 688, 240]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[700, 203, 861, 247]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 263, 170, 279]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 287, 344, 303]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[745, 287, 861, 303]]<|/det|> May/June 2021 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[798, 311, 861, 326]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 338, 376, 354]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 365, 667, 381]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 397, 218, 412]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 413, 850, 577]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 604, 208, 618]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 620, 693, 651]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[675, 688, 861, 810]]<|/det|>
For Examiner's Use
1
2
Total
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 826, 692, 843]]<|/det|> This document has 12 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 68, 702, 87]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 98, 91, 115]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 98, 725, 115]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the patterns produced by overlaid grids.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 127, 138, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 127, 675, 144]]<|/det|>
Grid A is the grid of parallel, equally spaced lines shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 212, 707, 529]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 590, 507, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 618, 875, 650]]<|/det|>
Take measurements to determine the average spacing \(s_{\mathrm{A}}\) between the centres of the lines on grid A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[519, 764, 875, 782]]<|/det|>
<form>s_{\mathrm{A}} = .................................................... mm [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 141, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 67, 863, 87]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with a second grid (labelled grid B) printed on a transparent sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 98, 171, 116]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 98, 499, 116]]<|/det|>
Place grid B on top of grid A in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 127, 168, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 127, 875, 160]]<|/det|>
Turn grid B so that there is a small angle \(G\) between the grids. A pattern of fringes will be produced, as shown in the example in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 170, 771, 490]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 509, 509, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 555, 166, 572]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 555, 529, 572]]<|/det|>
Do not take measurements from Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 583, 586, 601]]<|/det|>
Measure and record your value of \(G\) from Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 626, 875, 644]]<|/det|>
<form>G = .................................................... .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 672, 168, 691]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 672, 670, 691]]<|/det|>
The fringes make an angle \(F\) with grid A, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 701, 583, 719]]<|/det|>
Measure and record your value of \(F\) from Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 744, 875, 762]]<|/det|>
<form>F = .................................................... .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[851, 761, 875, 778]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 139, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 67, 717, 87]]<|/det|>
Rotate grid B and repeat **(b)** until you have six sets of values of \(G\) and \(F\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 97, 455, 116]]<|/det|>
Use values of \(G\) in the range \(0^{\circ}\) to \(20^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 126, 784, 145]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\sin F\) and \(\sin (F - G)\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 510, 876, 528]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 539, 138, 558]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 539, 176, 558]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 539, 700, 558]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\sin (F - G)\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\sin F\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 539, 876, 558]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 568, 171, 587]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 568, 435, 587]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 567, 876, 587]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[138, 597, 171, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 597, 579, 616]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 803, 875, 822]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 833, 875, 852]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 848, 876, 867]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 139, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 67, 693, 87]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the quantities \(F\) and \(G\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 97, 566, 116]]<|/det|>
\[\sin (F - G) = p\sin F + q\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 127, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
where \(p\) and \(q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 156, 641, 175]]<|/det|>
Use your answers in **(d)(iii)** to determine the values of \(p\) and \(q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[526, 288, 873, 308]]<|/det|>
<form>p = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[526, 319, 875, 337]]<|/det|>
<form>q = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 333, 876, 351]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 362, 136, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 361, 703, 381]]<|/det|>
The constant \(p\) is related to the spacing of the lines of grids A and B by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 384, 500, 415]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{S_{\mathrm{B}}}{S_{\mathrm{A}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 420, 443, 440]]<|/det|>
where \(s_{\mathrm{B}}\) is the line spacing of grid B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 450, 490, 470]]<|/det|>
Use your values of \(p\) and \(s_{\mathrm{A}}\) to calculate \(s_{\mathrm{B}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[519, 584, 876, 602]]<|/det|>
<form>s_{\mathrm{B}} = .................................................... mm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[791, 612, 876, 630]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 20]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 68, 702, 87]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 97, 92, 115]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 97, 710, 116]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the oscillations of a mass on a spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 127, 138, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 127, 175, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 127, 774, 145]]<|/det|>
● Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1 using the \(50\mathrm{g}\) mass hanger.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 156, 700, 437]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 450, 507, 468]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 480, 223, 497]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 480, 875, 513]]<|/det|>
Pull the mass hanger down by approximately \(1\mathrm{cm}\). Release it so that it oscillates vertically, with no swinging motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 524, 212, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 524, 710, 542]]<|/det|>
Take measurements to find the period \(T_{\mathrm{v}}\) of these oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[517, 625, 876, 644]]<|/det|>
<form>T_{\mathrm{v}} = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 657, 173, 675]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 657, 620, 675]]<|/det|>
Ensure that the mass hanger has stopped moving.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 686, 876, 718]]<|/det|>
Push the mass hanger approximately \(1\mathrm{cm}\) away from you. Release it so that it swings towards and away from you, with as little vertical oscillation as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 730, 207, 749]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[218, 730, 707, 749]]<|/det|>
Take measurements to find the period \(T_{\mathrm{S}}\) of these oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[517, 848, 876, 866]]<|/det|>
<form>T_{\mathrm{S}} = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[138, 67, 173, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 67, 660, 85]]<|/det|>
Explain whether your results in (c)(i) support the suggestion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 303, 876, 322]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 139, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 67, 170, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 67, 863, 85]]<|/det|>
